name: Madelyn Myers
comment info:
Putting a Price on Love
It was interesting to take a look at how much people spend on engagement rings, and how much of their salary they're spending on an engagement ring. The thing I’ve always heard about pricing for rings is that you are supposed to spend 2 months of your salary on an engagement ring. The graph has a significant drop off after about $3,000 dollars. There are of course outliers for the incredibly wealthy, with a spike in the data at 15,000+. But what really interests me is that the second lower graph shows that the people spending two months salary on an engagement ring are those who make less than 23,000. While anyone making more only spends around 2 weeks salary.  I wonder if that puts more strain on a poorer couples relationship, or if it means more because of the effort put into having enough to buy an engagement ring?

What I am noticing from this graph is that people are very cheap when it comes to buying their engagement rings. From the graph, you can see that more people spend less money on their engagement ring. From the second graph, it seems to be that people with a lower annual income spend more of their money on engagement rings. name: Jayden Xue
comment info:
I noticed that the information was different from logic's expectations. Usually, people with higher incomes would spend more on engagement rings since they have more money, while less well off consumers pay less. However, it was the complete opposite. Those with less than a $23,000 salary use 1/6 of their wages, while the highest income bracket of $90,000 spends 3.1%. I wonder if this is caused by hubris and humility. The latter might be arrogant and greedy, believing that they should keep most of their money and spend a little on a perceived small matter like engagement rings. On the other hand, those who can't live successful lives try to find other ways to live happily besides money, thus focusing on their partner. 

If I could create a catchy title for these two graphs, I would use "Engagement Rings Defy Logic!" This is due to the fact that while many believe it's important to have a significant other, the graph demonstrates that very little money is spent on it, and if a considerable amount is used, it is usually by people with low incomes.

name: Anh Bang
comment info:
Engagement rings or engagement stings?
The number of owners is inversely proportional to the rise in the cost of rings, as there are fewer people who can afford expensive rings. Yet the number of rings shot up at the 15000 dollars sign, signaling that $15000 somehow confers the status of luxury and class. However, the average salary in the US is $56,516, which somewhat shows the striking income gap in America.
Another finding points out that while those who have less than $23000 of annual income spend a whopping 2.2 months worth of salary on an engagement ring, those who earn just a bit more ($23000 to $40000) spend only 2 weeks worth of income. The number of weeks continues to lower, but not on a significant margin as the annual income increases. Engagement stings much more when you are poor.

name: Moderator Jen
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graphs:  “Engagement Economy“ by Avery of Hoggard High School in Wilmington, North Carolina, “The Rings of Love Become the Rings of Pain" by Mohamed of Academy for Software Engineering, New York, “Engagement Rings, Hand Over 2 Weeks Salary” by Riley of Bush, and "The Price of a Promise" by Soren of Eden Prairie, Minnesota.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, Feb. 13 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphics, and a few Stat Nuggets.

The next graph will be released Friday, Feb. 21, with moderation on Wednesday, Feb. 26.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to “What's Going On In This Graph?”  The topic --  contagious diseases.

You can see all of the released graphs on the “What’s Going On In This Graph?” homepage.  Or, go to our post “Looking for Graphs to Use in the Classroom? Here Are 34.” for an index by context and an index by type of graph.

The link for the Stat Nuggets archives ishttps://tinyurl.com/StatNuggets.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney of Boston, who is married and does not have an engagement ring, and Jen Mueller of St. Louis, who is married with an engagement ring.

name: Team Kingsbury
comment info:
Here at Eden Prairie our team was very intrigued by this graph representing the average cost of engagement rings boughten by adults. 
We noticed that the graph is very much right skewed. Additionally, we noticed that there is a jump around the $15K+ area which we hypothesized would be due to the richer population spending outrageous amounts on rings. 

We wondered why there were so many that spent above $15K+ on rings? What price point were the rings purchased at for the bottom graph? How big of their income was actually spent on this ring?

Finally our team composed a snappy headline that relates to this graph: 
"50% of marriages end in divorce. Is it worth the risk?"

name: Ben
comment info: The most noticeable aspect of this graph is that the majority of the sample set spend from $1K-$3K on rings, while few spend from $10K-$15K. Additionally, those who earn less than $23,000 annually will spend 16.7% of this income on a ring, which is 2.2 months worth of their earnings. Individuals who earn more than $90,000 only spend 3.1% of their income, meaning that only 1.6 weeks of their earnings go towards the engagement ring. By taking a step back from the graphical data, a class divide is emphasized largely through the part of the graph illustrating the percentage of their income that is spent on an engagement ring. Lower middle-class and lower-class people can be significantly harmed due to this institutionalized cultural value of purchasing an expensive physical manifestation of one’s love for their partner. This possible harm towards one’s financial well-being causes these rings’ importance to be questioned. If there was another socially acceptable way to propose to a loved one that did not cause one to spend 16.7% of their income, would there be a small percentage decrease in the class divide or low-income levels? This graph illustrates how much an adult will spend on an engagement ring. The majority of the population sampled spends between $1K-$3K on a ring. This trend could reflect on how many Americans can not afford to spend more than that range of money on a single physical object, while very few make enough annually to spend $10K or more on an engagement ring.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ben --

You’ve got to share with us a headline that captures your perceptive noticings and comments.  We’ll be waiting for it!  Thank you.

What do you notice?
I noticed that most people spend a thousand dollars or less on engagement rings. I also noticed that the more expensive the engagement ring amounts to, the less likely people will buy it. What do you wonder?

I wonder about this because usually when a person has a smaller income they act more frugal with the money than someone with a larger annual income. People with a smaller income could likely be more inclined to make a more financial meager decision than the financial wealthy.

What do you think is going on in this graph?
The graph shows that when a person has a smaller income it takes up a larger share of their income that means they are probably going to be less likely to buy a more expensive ring. This means that if a person with  much larger income wants to buy an engagement ring, they will be more inclined to buy a more expensive ring because the cost of the ring would take up a smaller amount of the person's income.

name: Avery Dixon
comment info:
First I notice that a plurality of people spend less than $1K Which… makes sense. However, it is a little interesting that it is not a majority. The second thing my eye is drawn too is the Huge discrepancy in portion of income, between people making less than 23,000 and everyone else.
  I suppose it's not surprising that the people that make the least play a larger portion of their income on engagement rings but what is fascinating how the discrepancy is set up. After you get out of the >$23000 bracket the rings portion of income almost Plateaus at 2 weeks. Where the lowest bracket is chilling at almost 2 months. Now this could be because engagement rings don't scale down to that low of income. It is also going to be affected more by extremes as the amount of starting money is already so low. Keep in mind this bracket could contain anyone making less than $23000. Which is where I have to believe the discrepancy is created. Look at all the following brackets, whose proportions are relatively even.
  I have sort of already mentioned it. I believe the > $23000 bracket is being raised most by people making much less than $23000. Such as a homeless man buying a ring with 8 months savings. Other than that the graph is pretty relaxed with proportion of income trending slightly down as income increases. The first graph does have a spike at the 15k+ price but that should be no surprise as the price includes the infinity above it. Those are the only considerable outliers.

name: Eli McCutchan
comment info:
More Money, Less Spent on Engagement Rings???

I found the survey was made up of 1,640 people, and the data was gathered in January. The graphs clearly show a trend of engagement ring costs peaking at the cheapest of under $500. Nevertheless, I wonder if the poll had more people and I'm curious if the chart would have been different in a later month near the tax cutoff. I also noticed those who made less money, often spent a greater percentage of income on the rings.
	I wonder why there was such a $15,000 spike on a ring relative to the ring that priced less but were still really costly. I wonder if this data can be used to evaluate the hard work and salary in different racial-economic classes. If these were based on different factors, such as race, gender, occupation, and age, would the graph trend the same way?
	Essentially, the lower amount of income a person generates, they are more likely to spend a greater percentage of their income on the engagement ring. This also enforces the common American ideal that you should put 1-3 months salary down on a ring, and is slowly disappearing for the middle to high class.

name: Kimber Hageman
comment info:
I notice that there is a clear trend of more Americans opting to buy cheaper engagement rings. Due to the fact that Americans on the lower end of the income spectrum spend longer saving for an engagement ring, as shown in the second graph, numerous Americans are choosing to buy less expensive rings. Additionally, the income gap in the United States ensures that the vast majority of Americans are not able to spend an exorbitant amount of money on unnecessary items like engagement rings. 

I wonder why there is a spike in the number of people purchasing rings over $15,000.  I wonder why the group that makes $23,000 to $40,000 spends so much less time paying off their ring than the lowest income group. I also wonder what the average cost of a ring is for each income group. I think those added statistics would shed some light on exactly why each income group has the time frame that it does to save up for the ring. 

The graph overall shows the general trend of income that someone makes versus how much they spend on an engagement ring. There is a substantial drop-off after $3000, showing how Americans are generally spending a lower amount on engagement rings overall. This trend may be due to people making less money overall or people just choosing to save their money.

replies.comment info: @Ellen That is a good observation. I also noticed that people who made less took longer to pay it back. I wonder how expensive the rings were that took the longest to pay back.

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: @Ellen I also noticed the gray numbers beside of the months. I was wondering if maybe that was the percentage of people.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Ellen  this comment makes sense because people that make more money have the capacity to pay things faster.
